titles.title: Expressing the sense of Congress concerning the safety and well-being of United States citizens injured while traveling in Mexico.

action.text: Referred to the House Committee on International Relations.
Referred to the Subcommittee on the Western Hemisphere.
Subcommittee Consideration and Mark-up Session Held.
Forwarded by Subcommittee to Full Committee (Amended) by Voice Vote.
Committee Consideration and Mark-up Session Held.

calendar.text: Committee Agreed to Seek Consideration Under Suspension of the Rules, (Amended) by Voice Vote.

action.text: Mr. Bereuter moved to suspend the rules and agree to the resolution, as amended.
Considered under suspension of the rules.
DEBATE - The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H. Con. Res. 232.

vote.text: On motion to suspend the rules and agree to the resolution, as amended Agreed to by voice vote.

action.text: Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
Received in the Senate and referred to the Committee on Foreign Relations.
Senate Committee on Foreign Relations discharged by Unanimous Consent.

vote.text: Resolution agreed to in Senate without amendment and with a preamble by Unanimous Consent.

action.text: Message on Senate action sent to the House.

bill.summary: 7/24/2000--Passed House amended. Expresses the sense of Congress that, in order to protect the safety and well-being of United States citizens traveling in Mexico, the President should continue to negotiate with the Government of Mexico to establish a humanitarian exemption to Mexican bond requirements, to ensure the expedited return of U.S. citizens injured in Mexico to the United States for necessary medical treatment.
